instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.U5110: What is U5110? This chip is responsible for SMC_RESET_L in many Macbook models..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not power on, orange/green light.
threads.message: so, i got this machine as water damage there is no sign of it, inside the machine. i took out the board and made some measurements. ppbus, is 12.64v, i checked data lines, they are open. i checked <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>, and its fluctuating. <SIGNAL>PM_BATTLOW_L</SIGNAL> is fluctuating too. my suspect is that the SMC is damaged, but i dont wanna mess with it, whitout a second opinion. so do i reball/replace SMC or where do i check?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not power on, orange/green light.
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and 3V42 steady voltages?
You must get stable <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> signal.
Check <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> area and post its voltages.
Test disconnecting TP/KB cables too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not power on, orange/green light.
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> fluctuating between 12.55v and 12.66v. 3vs42 stable at 3.42v. <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is at 2.34v.

As for <CHIP>U5110</CHIP>

pin 1 - 3.42v
pin 2- 0v
pin 3-3.42v
pin 4- 3.30v
pin 5-2.16v
pin 6- 3.10v
pin 7-3.42v
pin 8-3.31v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not power on, orange/green light.
threads.message: TP and KB are disconnected of course!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not power on, orange/green light.
threads.message:
Not too much things connected there.
First be sure <RESISTOR>R5100</RESISTOR> is not affected by corrosion.
Next remove <RESISTOR>R7100</RESISTOR> and see if <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> goes high.
J6100 is suspect too; you may need to clean, or remove it.
If still the same, change <CHIP>U5110</CHIP>.
For the last remains SMC.
You can try reballing it first...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not power on, orange/green light.
threads.message: resoldered <RESISTOR>R5100</RESISTOR> to make sure it has good contact with pads. removed <RESISTOR>R7100</RESISTOR>, smc reset l increased to 3.12v....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not power on, orange/green light.
threads.message: If you get steady high <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> without <RESISTOR>R7100</RESISTOR>, then replace <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not power on, orange/green light.
threads.message: i did all you told me to before messing with the smc......then i reflowed smc, and board is now dead haha. i guess ill have to get some scraps board go replace it. and a new stencil, the one i have its bent...ill update once i get everything i need to fix this.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not power on, orange/green light.
threads.message:
If <SIGNAL>SMC_REESET_L</SIGNAL> went high after <RESISTOR>R7100</RESISTOR> removed, didn't test if board starts that time?
I hoped you make the mentioned steps one by one.

Try to reball SMC again.
Use solder paste, not balls...
